newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight drops to 6.2/3 pct vs 8.0 on maturity.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight drops to 6.2/3 pct vs 8.0 on maturity.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate dropped to 6.2/3 percent against 8.0 percent previously due to the maturity of a central bank deposit, dealers said on Tuesday.
They said the maturity gave the system fresh liquidity, which is expected to leave the system on Wednesday after payment for a Bank Negara bill issue.

The dealers said there were two issues of Bank Negara bills totalling one billion ringgit. While 500 million ringgit will come from a maturing bill issue, a large part of the rest would come from the central bank maturity.
The maturing deposit was raised by Bank Negara as part of its open market intervention operations last month.
It regularly intervenes in the money market to control liquidity and set interest rates, but it does not disclose the amount it has raised.
Earlier, other interbank rates were mostly steady as banks held back funds for the Bank Negara bill issue, dealers said.
One-week money was at 7.00/10 percent against 7.05/15, while two-week at 7.10/20 and one-month at 7.15/20 were unchanged.
Two-month at 7.15/18, three-month at 7.16/19 and six-month at 7.20/23 were three to five basis points lower.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were marginally higher though volumes shrank due to a steady trend in the cash market, futures dealers said.
At 0730 GMT, the Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate December contract was up one point at 92.85. Volumes for all contracts was just 74 lots.
